Asian stocks fell in early trade on Monday, as investors turned to haven assets after North Korea tested a nuclear bomb on Sunday.The Singapore-traded SGX Nifty, an early indicator of NSE Nifty 50 Index’s performance in India, declined 0.23 percent to 9,991 as of 6:45 a.m.Here’s a quick look at all that could influence equities on Monday.






Global CuesU.S. stocks rose and Treasuries declined as reports showing a gain in consumer sentiment and an increase in manufacturing offset a mediocre August employment report.






President Donald Trump threatened to increase economic sanctions and halt trade with any nation doing business with North Korea, and his defense chief said the U.S. has “many military options” after the regime said it successfully tested a hydrogen bomb with “unprecedentedly big power.”





North Korea conducts first nuclear test since Trump took power.https://t.co/5dFDqgNGhn pic.twitter.com/RST7LJM057— BloombergQuint (@BloombergQuint) September 3, 2017






Asian CuesJapan’s Topix index lost 0.4 percent, while South Korea’s Kospi index lost 1.1 percent and the S&P/ASX 200 Index in Sydney declined 0.3 percent.The MSCI Asia Pacific Index fell 0.2 percent.Commodity CuesWTI crude was rose 0.36 percent to $47.46 a barrel in early Monday trade, while Brent slid 0.4 percent to $52.52 a barrelOil prices ended a bit higher on Friday, but still posted a weekly loss as energy markets continued to weigh the impact of Hurricane Harvey will be on crude production and refinery demand in the Gulf of Mexico region.Spot gold trades higher at $1335.45 an ounce, the highest in in 10 monthsICE sugar ended lower at 13.75 cents a pound, down 4.51 percentShanghai ExchangeSteel trades higher for second day; up 3.88 percentAluminium trades higher for fourth consecutive session; up 1.02 percentZinc trades higher; up 1.39 percentCopper trades higher; up 0.21 percentRubber trades higher for third day; up 3.43 percent
title: All You Need To Know Going Into Trade On September 04
